channel.title: v1.0 on Understanding the 2016 Election
channel.description: Recent content in v1.0 on Understanding the 2016 Election

item.title: Basic Performance Analysis
item.description: Where did Democrats have a large percentage of the vote? Where did Republicans have a large percentage of the vote? Where and how did the Democratic turnout change? Where and how did the Republican turnout change? Where was the net Republican shift? Methods To understand what made 2016 different from 2012, we can just subtract. We can approximate the Trump effect as the difference between the 2016 Republicans Presidential vote percentage and the 2012 percentage to see where Trump outperformed Romney (and won while Romney lost). Results For example, in Winnebago, Wisconsin, Romney got 47% of the vote and Trump got 50.5%. This is a +3% Republican shift that flipped the county from blue to red. In the map above, we clearly see that Trump underperformed Romney in Utah and parts of Idaho. (This makes sense, since Evan McMullin was a spoiler candidate and Mormons abandoned Trump in droves.) However, Trump overperformed in Missouri, Iowa, Ohio, and generally in the Great Lakes region.
